body:
Sometimes opportunities that seem great in the abstract are unbearable when rendered into concrete detail. Take this scenario, for example: A biologist discovers a substance that will allow you to live for 200 years.

Most of us would jump at the chance to live for two centuries. What if, however, you had to live inside of a germ-free room from age thirty on without any direct human contact? You would have books, and television, and specially made food, but friends and family would only be able to communicate with you via computer screens.

Or, let's say you still aged pretty much like we do now. Even though you would live longer, in your second century of life your spine would curve, your vision would dim, your hearing fail, and you would have all the pains and frailty that the elderly have normally. For a hundred years you would hobble about on arthritic joints, a prisoner to your wasting body.

So next time someone makes you an offer that seems too good to be true, look carefully at the fine print. The Devil is in the details!
title: The Devil is in the Details

senses.difference: (obsolete) Extracted.
Considered apart from any application to a particular object; removed from; apart from; separate; abstracted.
Absent in mind.
Apart from practice or reality; not concrete; ideal; vague; theoretical; impersonal.
Difficult to understand; abstruse.
(art) Free from representational qualities.
(logic) General (as opposed to particular).
Particular, perceivable, real.
senses.example: Fuzzy videotapes and distorted sound recordings are not concrete evidence that bigfoot exists.

senses.difference: Not abstract.
senses.example: Once arrested, I realized that handcuffs are concrete, even if my concept of what is legal wasn’t.

senses.difference: Made of concrete building material.
senses.example: The office building had concrete flower boxes out front.

senses.difference: Of superior quality.
Of a particular grade of quality, usually between very good and very fine, and below mint.
of weather: sunny and not raining
(informal) Being acceptable, adequate, passable, or satisfactory.
(informal) Good-looking, attractive.
Consisting of especially minute particulate; made up of particularly small pieces.
Particularly slender; especially thin, narrow, or of small girth.
Made of slender or thin filaments.
acting in the interest of good; ethical (''good intentions'')
Useful for a particular purpose (it’s a good watch).
Of food, edible; not stale or rotten.
senses.example: still good

senses.difference: Of food, having a particularly pleasant taste.
Of food, healthful; full of vitamins and minerals.
senses.example: good for you

senses.difference: Pleasant; enjoyable.
senses.example: a good time

senses.difference: Of people, competent or talented.
senses.example: a good swimmer

senses.difference: Effective.
senses.example: a good worker

senses.difference: Favourable.
senses.example: a good omen

senses.difference: Beneficial; worthwhile.
senses.example: a good job

senses.difference: Very big, large scale.
senses.example: A great storm is approaching our shores.

senses.difference: Very good.
senses.example: Dinner was great.

senses.difference: important title
(notcomp) Of or belonging to the species Homo sapiens or its closest relatives.
having the nature or attributes of a human species
Following in a sequence.
Being closer to the present location than all other items.
nearest date, time, space or order
{{context|of a statement}} concurring with a given set of facts; factually correct.
(logic) A state in Boolean logic that indicates an affirmative or positive result.
senses.example: "A and B" is true if and only if "A" is true and "B" is true.

senses.difference: Loyal, faithful.
senses.example: He’s turned out to be a true friend. (See below, "Compound Words and Terms")

senses.difference: Genuine.
senses.example: This is true Parmesan cheese.

senses.difference: Legitimate.
senses.example: The true king has returned!

senses.difference: On all sides; around.
senses.example: * 'Tis time to look about. - Shakespeare, King Lear, IV-vii

senses.difference: In circuit; circularly; by a circuitous way; around the outside; as, a mile about, and a third of a mile across.
Here and there; around; in one place and another.
senses.example: * Wandering about from house to house. - 1 Timothy 5:13

senses.difference: Nearly; approximately; with close correspondence, in quality, manner, degree, etc.; as, about as cold; about as high; -- also of quantity, number, time.
senses.example: * There fell ... about three thousand men. - Exodus 22:28

senses.difference: To a reserved position; half round; in the opposite direction; on the opposite tack; as, to face about; to turn one's self about.
inside
Within or towards the interior of something, especially a building.
senses.example: It started raining, so I went inside.

senses.difference: Over a great distance in space.
senses.example: He threw the ball long.

senses.difference: For a particular duration.
senses.example: How long is it until the next bus arrives?

senses.difference: For a long duration.<!--OK to use "long" in this definition, as here it is an adjective-->
senses.example: Will this interview take long?

senses.difference: Under normal conditions or circumstances; usually; most of the time
senses.example: Normally, I eat breakfast at 6am, but today, I got up late and didn't eat until 9.

senses.difference: In the expected or customary manner.
senses.example: Lisa ate normally, until she realised that she was late for choir, when she sped up.

senses.difference: At this time
In a manner, or regarding a topic, different from that of the immediately past.
senses.example: Now, we all want the best for our children.

senses.difference: In the context of urgency.
senses.example: Now listen, we must do something about this.

senses.difference: to an operating state
senses.example: turn the television on

senses.difference: along, forwards (continuing an action)
senses.example: drive on, rock on

senses.difference: along, forwards (continuing an action)
senses.example: drive on, rock on

senses.difference: (cricket) in, or towards the half of the field on the same side as the batsman's legs; the left side for a right-handed batsman; leg
at present, as in the past
nevertheless
senses.example: I’m not hungry, but I’ll still manage to find room for dessert.

senses.difference: to an even greater degree. (Used to modify comparative adjectives or adverbs.)
senses.example: Tom is tall; Dick is taller; Harry is still taller.

senses.difference: Likewise; also; in addition.
more than enough; ''as too much''

Definite grammatical article that implies necessarily that the entity it articulates is presupposed; something already mentioned, or completely specified later in the same sentence, or assumed already completely specified. Compare I’m reading a book with
senses.example: The street in front of your house. (But compare a street in Paris)

senses.difference: stressed, indicating that the object in question is the only one worthy of attention
With an adjectival noun, as in “the hungry” to mean “hungry people”
With a superlative, it refers to the same thing which the superlative applies to.
senses.example: That apple pie was the best.

senses.difference: Used as an alternative to a possessive pronoun before body parts
Used with the name of a member of a class to refer to all things in that class
Must; need to; to be required to. Indicates obligation
senses.example: You have to wear a seat belt.

senses.difference: (with be) Must (logical conclusion)
senses.example: That has to be the postman

senses.difference: As a past-tense form of will.
Used as the auxiliary of the simple conditional mood (with a bare infinitive); indicating an action or state that is conditional on another.
Used to connect two similar words, phrases, et cetera
Used at the end of a list to indicate the last item.
senses.example: bread, butter and cheese

senses.difference: Used to string together sentences or sentence fragments in chronological order
Used to show causation
Except (for), excluding.
senses.example: I like everything but that. I have no choice but to leave.

senses.difference: On the contrary, but rather (introducing a word or clause that contrasts with or contradicts the preceding clause or sentence without the not).
senses.example: I am not rich but poor.

senses.difference: However, although, nevertheless (implies that the following clause is contrary to prior belief or contrasts with or contradicts the preceding clause or sentence).
senses.example: She is very old but still attractive. You told me I could do that but she said that I could not.

senses.difference: {{non-gloss definition|Connecting noun clause (as involving reported speech etc.)}}
senses.example: He told me that the book is a good read.

senses.difference: connecting clause indicating purpose
every individual of the given class
Throughout the whole of (a stated period of time; generally used with units of a day or longer).
senses.example: The store is open all day and all night. (= The store is open throughout the whole of the day and the whole of the night.)

senses.difference: Completely.
senses.example: You’ve got it all wrong.

senses.difference: The (thing) here {{i|used in indicating something or someone nearby}}.
senses.example: This classroom is where I learned to read and write.

senses.difference: known (thing) just mentioned
known (thing) about to be mentioned
known (thing) that the speaker does not think is known to the audience
The whole duration of a being, whether animal, vegetable, or other kind; lifetime.
part of the duration of a being or thing between its beginning and any given time
The latter part of life; an advanced period of life, eld; seniority; state of being old.
senses.example: Wisdom doesn't necessarily come with age.

senses.difference: One of the stages of life; as, the age of infancy, of youth, etc.
time of life when one attains full person rights
The time of life at which some particular power or capacity is understood to become vested.
senses.example: the age of consent

senses.difference: A particular period of time in history, as distinguished from others.
senses.example: the golden age

senses.difference: A great period in the history of the Earth.
The people who live at a particular period.
Hence, a generation.
senses.example: There are three ages living in her house.

senses.difference: A long time.
senses.example: It's been an age since we last saw you.

senses.difference: The physical structure of a human or animal seen as one single organism.
senses.example: I saw them walking from a distance, their bodies strangely angular in the dawn light.

senses.difference: The fleshly or corporeal nature of a human, as opposed to the spirit or soul.
senses.example: The body is driven by desires, but the soul is at peace.

senses.difference: A corpse.
senses.example: Her body was found at four o'clock, just two hours after the murder.

senses.difference: The torso, the main structure of a human or animal frame excluding the extremities (limbs, head, tail).
senses.example: The boxer took a blow to the body.

senses.difference: largest or most important part of anything (eg car bodywork)
(archaic) The section of a dress extending from the neck to the waist, excluding the arms.
senses.example: Penny was in the scullery, pressing the body of her new dress.

senses.difference: An organisation, company or other authoritative group.
senses.example: The local train operating company is the managing body for this section of track.

senses.difference: group having a common purpose or opinion
collection of knowledge
Any physical object or material thing.
senses.example: All bodies are held together by internal forces.

senses.difference: substance, material presence
(uncountable) Comparative viscosity, solidity or substance (in wine, colours etc.).
senses.example: The rioja, sadly, lacked body.

senses.difference: (programming) The code of a subroutine, contrasted to its signature and parameters.<sup>W</sup>
collection of sheets of paper bound together containing printed or written material
A record of betting (from the use of a notebook to record what each person has bet).
senses.example: I'm running a book on who is going to win the race.

senses.difference: convenient collection of small paper items, such as stamps
major division of a published work, larger than a chapter
The script of a musical.
usually in plural: records of the accounts of a business
A record of betting (from the use of a notebook to record what each person has bet).
senses.example: I'm running a book on who is going to win the race.

senses.difference: 100 years
Roman army type unit
political division of Rome
(Cricket) a hundred runs scored either by a single player in one innings, or by two players in a partnership.
(context|US|cycling) A ride 100 miles in length.
(countable) An opportunity or possibility.
senses.example: We have the chance

senses.difference: (uncountable) Random occurrence; luck.
senses.example: Why leave it to chance when a few simple steps will secure the desired outcome?

senses.difference: (countable) The probability of something happening.
senses.example: There is a 30% chance of rain tomorrow.

senses.difference: (computing) A programmable device that performs mathematical calculations and logical operations, especially one that can process, store and retrieve large amounts of data very quickly.
(dated) A person employed to perform computations.
an act of touching physically
an establishment of communication
colloquial: a contact lens
electrical: a device designed for repetitive connections
Someone with whom one is in communication.
senses.example: The salesperson had a whole binder full of contacts for potential clients.

senses.difference: (countable) Something small enough to escape casual notice.
senses.example: Note this fine detail in the lower left corner.

senses.difference: (uncountable) A profusion of details.
senses.example: This etching is full of fine detail

senses.difference: Something considered trivial enough to ignore.
senses.example: I don't concern myself with the details of accounting

senses.difference: ''plural'': personal information
military: temporary unit
(theology) A creature of hell.
(theology) (the devil or the Devil) The chief devil; Satan.
The bad part of the conscience; the opposite to the angel.
A wicked or naughty person, or one who harbors reckless, spirited energy, especially in a mischievous way; usually said of a young child.
A thing that is awkward or difficult to understand or do.
euphemistically, with an article: Hell (as an intensifier)
A person, especially a man; used to express a particular opinion of him, usually in the phrases poor devil and lucky devil.
in Christian Science, an evil or erroneous entity
(countable) A father, mother and their sons and daughters; also called nuclear family.
senses.example: Her nuclear family was very small.

senses.difference: (countable) A group of people related by blood, marriage, law, or custom.
(countable) A kin, tribe; also called extended family.
rank in a taxonomic classification, above both genus and species
taxon at this rank
(countable) A group of people who live together.
senses.example: This is my fraternity family at the university.

senses.difference: group of people similar to (2)
(uncountable) Collectively, people who are members of one's intimate social group.
senses.example: They treated me like family.

senses.difference: (countable|music) A group of instrument having the same basic method of tone production.
senses.example: the brass family

senses.difference: (countable|linguistics) A group of languages believed to have descended from the same ancestral language.
senses.example: the Indo-European language family

senses.difference: any substance consumed by living organisms to sustain life
anything intended to supply energy or nourishment of other forms
(countable) A foodstuff.
senses.example: This shop stocks many hundreds of different foods.

senses.difference: person whose company one enjoys
A boyfriend or girlfriend.
person with whom you are acquainted
person who provides assistance
A person who backs something.
senses.example: I’m not a friend of cheap wine.

senses.difference: An object or idea that can be used for good.
senses.example: Google is your friend.

senses.difference: form of address used to warn someone
(biology) The small mass of cells from which a new organism develops; a seed, bud or spore.
A pathogenic microorganism.
An idea that forms the basis of some project.
(uncountable) The sense used to perceive sound.
senses.example: My hearing isn't what it used to be, but I still heard that noise.

senses.difference: (uncountable) A proceeding at which discussions are heard.
senses.example: There will be a public hearing to discuss the new traffic light.

senses.difference: (uncountable) (legal) A legal procedure done before a judge, without a jury, as with an evidentiary hearing.
joint with freedom to rotate
rigid joint
part of the body where bones join
point of a rigid joint, means of joining in carpentry
(geology) A fracture in which the strata are not offset; a geologic joint.
(slang) A restaurant, bar, nightclub or similar business.
senses.example: It was the kind of joint you wouldn't want your boss to see you in.

senses.difference: (slang) (always with the) prison
senses.example: I'm just trying to stay out of the joint.

senses.difference: (slang) A marijuana cigarette.
senses.example: After locking the door and closing the shades, they lit the joint.

senses.difference: The state between birth and death
a status given to an entity with the properties of replication and metabolism
(philosophy) The essence of the manifestation and the foundation of the being.
(context|phenomenology) the subjective and inner manifestation of the individual.
the essence of God
The world in general; existence.
senses.example: Man's life on this planet has been marked by continual conflict.

senses.difference: A worthwhile existence.
senses.example: He gets up early in the morning, works all day long — even on weekends — and hardly sees his family. That's no life!

senses.difference: inheritantly part of a person's existence
(colloquial) A life sentence; a term of imprisonment of a convict until his or her death.
duration
A proposal that has been made.
senses.example: What's in his offer?

senses.difference: Something put forth, bid, proffered or tendered.
senses.example: His offer was $3.50 per share.

senses.difference: law: invitation to enter binding contract
a chance for advancement, progress or profit
a favorable circumstance or occasion
{{italbrac|countable and uncountable}} An ache or bodily suffering, or an instance of this; an unpleasant sensation, resulting from a derangement of functions, disease, or injury by violence; hurt.
senses.example: The greatest difficulty lies in treating patients with chronic pain.

senses.difference: (uncountable) The condition or fact of suffering or anguish especially mental, as opposed to pleasure; torment; distress; sadness; grief; solicitude; disquietude.
senses.example: In the final analysis, pain is a fact of life.

senses.difference: (countable) An annoying person or thing.
senses.example: Your mother is a right pain.

senses.difference: suffering as punishment
result of printing process
A visible impression on a surface.
senses.example: * Using a crayon, the girl made a print of the leaf under the page.

senses.difference: A person incarcerated in a prison, while on trial or serving a sentence.
(figurative) Any person held against his or her will.
space {{jump|t|space|s
division in a building {{jump|t|part of a building|s
An outline of the plot of a dramatic or literary work.
screenplay or an outline or treatment thereof
An outline or model of an expected or supposed sequence of events.
A physical divider intended to block an area from view.
A material woven from fine wires intended to block animals or large particles from passing while allowing gasses, liquids and finer particles to pass.
The informational viewing area of electronic output devices; the result of the output.
The viewing area of a movie, or moving picture or slide presentation
(basketball) An offensive tactic in which a player stands so as to block a defender from reaching a teammate.
(baseball) The protective netting which protects the audience from flying objects
senses.example: Jones caught the foul up against the screen.

senses.difference: the stone classification device
in printing
A person or thing's backbone; the series of bones collectively from one's (literal or figurative) head to tail or pelvis.
A rigid, pointed surface protuberance or needle-like structure on an animal, shell, or plant.
metaphor for courage or assertiveness
The narrow, bound edge of a book.
Physical matter; material.
The essential part of anything; the most vital part.
true meaning
Considerable wealth or resources.
senses.example: A man of substance.

senses.difference: drugs
senses.example: substance abuse

senses.difference: (uncountable) Collectively, the programs broadcast via the medium of television.
senses.example: ... fifty-seven channels and nothing on [television].

senses.difference: television set
program broadcasting
inevitable passing of events
(uncountable) A quantity of availability in time.
senses.example: More time is needed to complete the project.

senses.difference: measurement of a quantity of time
slang: serving of a prison sentence
time of day, as indicated by a clock, etc
(countable) A particular moment or hour; the appropriate moment or hour for something (esp. with prepositional phrase or imperfect subjunctive).
senses.example: It’s time for bed. It’s time to sleep.

senses.difference: measurement under some system of the time of day or moment in time
numerical indication of a particular moment in time
(countable) An instance or occurrence.
senses.example: When was the last time we went out? I don’t remember.

senses.difference: (countable) An experience.
senses.example: We had a wonderful time at the party.

senses.difference: (countable) An era; (with the, sometimes in plural) the current era, the current state of affairs.
senses.example: Roman times; the time of the dinosaurs.

senses.difference: (uncountable) (with possessive) A person's youth or young adulthood, as opposed to the present day.
senses.example: In my time, we respected our elders.

senses.difference: person's experiences or biography
The cardinality of the set {0, 1}; one plus one. This many: ••. Ordinal: second.
Describing a set or group with two components.
(uncountable) The sense or ability of sight.
(countable) Something imaginary one thinks one sees.
senses.example: He tried drinking from the pool of water, but realized it was only a vision.

senses.difference: ideal or goal
(countable) A religious or mystical experience of a supernatural appearance.
senses.example: He had a vision of the Virgin Mary.

senses.difference: (countable) A person or thing of extraordinary beauty.
time it takes for the Earth to complete one revolution of the Sun
{{context|by extension}} The time it takes for any planetary body to make one revolution around another body.
senses.example: Mars goes around the sun once in a Martian year, or 1.88 Earth years.

senses.difference: A period between set dates that mark a year, from January 1 to December 31 by the Gregorian calendar.
senses.example: A normal year has 365 full days, but there are 366 days in a leap year.

senses.difference: A scheduled part of a calendar year spent in a specific activity.
senses.example: During this school year I have to get up at 6:30 to catch the bus.

senses.difference: (sciences) A Julian year, exactly 365.25 days, represented by "a".
a level or grade at school or college
In or very near a particular place.
senses.example: At that precise position, at Jim’s house.

senses.difference: {{italbrac|indicating time}} Simultaneous.
senses.example: At six o’clock, at closing time.

senses.difference: In the direction of (often in an unfocused or uncaring manner).
senses.example: He threw the ball at me, he shouted at her.

senses.difference: Towards.
senses.example: The astronauts headed for the moon.

senses.difference: Directed at, intended to belong to.
senses.example: I have something for you.

senses.difference: Supporting (opposite of against).
senses.example: All those for the motion raise your hands.

senses.difference: Because of.
senses.example: He wouldn't apologize; and just for that, she refused to help him.

senses.difference: With the source or provenance of or at.
senses.example: This wine comes from France.

senses.difference: With the origin, starting point or initial reference of or at.
senses.example: He had books piled from floor to ceiling.

senses.difference: With the separation, exclusion or differentiation of.
senses.example: An umbrella protects from the sun.

senses.difference: Contained by.
senses.example: The dog is in the kennel.

senses.difference: Surrounded by.
senses.example: We are in the enemy camp.

senses.difference: part, member of
Pertaining to (that particular thing).
senses.example: He has passed in English.

senses.difference: After a period of time.
senses.example: They said they would call us in a week.

senses.difference: by the virtue of
Into.
senses.example: Less water gets in your boots this way.

senses.difference: Going inside (of)
senses.example: Mary danced into the house.

senses.difference: Going to a geographic region.
senses.example: We left the house and walked into the street.

senses.difference: against, with force
Producing, becoming
senses.example: I carved the piece of driftwood into a sculpture of a whale.

senses.difference: (colloquial) Intensely interested in or attracted to.
senses.example: I'm really into Shakespeare right now.

senses.difference: (mathematics) Taking distinct arguments to distinct values.
senses.example: The exponential function maps the set of real numbers into itself.

senses.difference: Belonging to or associated with.
senses.example: The properties of this substance are interesting. <!-- Belonging to (better example?) -->

senses.difference: containing, comprising or made from
about the old days
connects a quantifier with quantified
{{non-gloss definition|Connects a noun derived from a verb with the object of that verb.}}
senses.example: Some resisted the admission of the new members to the club.

senses.difference: (''time'') before
connecting a jurisdiction to its name
indicative of age
Positioned at the upper surface of, touching from above.
senses.example: on the table; on the couch

senses.difference: covering
At the date of.
senses.example: Born on the 4th of July.

senses.difference: Dealing with the subject of, about, or concerning something.
senses.example: A book on history.

senses.difference: Touching; hanging from.
senses.example: The fruit ripened on the trees.

senses.difference: math:having ''V'' as both domain and codomain
math:having ''V''<sup>n</sup> as domain and ''V'' as codomain
Because of, or due to something.
senses.example: To arrest someone on suspicion of bribery.

senses.difference: Paid for by.
senses.example: The drinks are on me tonight, boys.

senses.difference: used to indicate means or medium
In the direction of, and arriving at (indicating destination).
senses.example: We are walking to the shop.

senses.difference: used after certain adjectives to indicate a relationship
(arithmetic) {{non-gloss definition|Used to indicate ratios.}}
senses.example: one to one = 1:1

senses.difference: used to indicated exponentiation
{{non-gloss definition|Used to indicate the indirect object.}}
senses.example: I gave the book to him.

senses.difference: (context|time) Preceding
senses.example: ten to ten = 9:50; We're going to leave at ten to (the hour).

senses.difference: by way of; passing through
senses.example: They drove from New York to Los Angeles via Omaha.

senses.difference: by (means of); using (a medium).
senses.example: I'll send you the information via e-mail.

senses.difference: against
senses.example: He picked a fight with the class bully.

senses.difference: in the company of; alongside, along side of; close to; near to:
senses.example: He went with his friends.

senses.difference: in addition to; as an accessory to:
senses.example: She owns a motorcycle with a sidecar.

senses.difference: in support of:
senses.example: We are with you all the way.

senses.difference: expressing manner
as an instrument; by means of
senses.example: cut with a knife

senses.difference: (obsolete) as nourishment, more recently replaced by on
(personal) me and at least one other person; the objective case of we.
(slang) me
senses.example: Give us a look at your paper.

senses.difference: subject pronoun: the person being addressed
object pronoun: the person being addressed
subject pronoun: the group being addressed
object pronoun: the group being addressed
{{i|subject pronoun}} Anyone, one; an unspecified individual.
senses.example: You have to be at least 36 inches high to go on this ride.

senses.difference: belonging to you (singular; one owner)
belonging to you (plural; more owners)
belonging to you (to be sorted)
transitive: cause to grow old
intransitive: become old
(transitive) To grant, give, admit, accord, afford, or yield; to let one have.
senses.example: To allow a servant his liberty

senses.difference: (transitive) To acknowledge; to accept as true; to concede; to accede to an opinion.
senses.example: To allow a right; to allow a claim; to allow the truth of a proposition.

senses.difference: to take into account as a deduction or an addition
(transitive) To grant license to; to permit; to consent to.
senses.example: To allow a son to be absent

senses.difference: (intransitive) To let something happen, to admit; to concede
to make allowance
(intransitive) To occupy a place.
senses.example: The cup is on the table.

senses.difference: occur, take place
{{intransitive|without predicate}} To exist.
senses.example: The meaning of life, or how we have come to be.

senses.difference: elliptical form of "be here", or similar
(transitive|copulative) Used to indicate that the subject and object are the same.
senses.example: Ignorance is bliss.

senses.difference: (transitive|copulative|mathematics) Used to indicate that the values on either side of an equation are the same.
senses.example: 3 times 5 is fifteen.

senses.difference: used to indicate that the subject plays the role of the predicate nominative
(transitive|copulative) Used to connect a noun to an adjective that describes it.
senses.example: The sky is blue.

senses.difference: (transitive|copulative) Used to indicate that the subject has the qualities described by a noun or noun phrase.
senses.example: The sky is a deep blue today.

senses.difference: (context|transitive|auxiliary) Used to form the passive voice.
senses.example: The dog was drowned by the boy.

senses.difference: (context|transitive|auxiliary) Used to form the continuous forms of various tenses.
senses.example: The woman is walking.

senses.difference: (archaic) Used to form the perfect aspect with certain intransitive verbs. Often still used for to go
senses.example: They are not yet come back. (Macbeth by William Shakespeare) (instead of They have not yet come back.)

senses.difference: (context|transitive|auxiliary) Used to form future tenses, especially the future subjunctive.
senses.example: I am to leave tomorrow.

senses.difference: Used to indicate age.
senses.example: This building is three hundred years old.

senses.difference: Used to indicate height.
senses.example: He was five-eight.

senses.difference: Used to indicate time of day, day of the week, or date.
senses.example: It is almost eight.

senses.difference: (often|impersonal) Used to indicate weather, air quality, or the like.
senses.example: It’s hot in Arizona, but it’s not usually humid.

senses.difference: (rfv-sense) Used to indicate temperature.
senses.example: It’s in the eighties outside, and next week it’s expected to be in the nineties! (Fahrenheit degrees)

senses.difference: (transitive|now|_|formal) To impart or transmit (to another); to give a share of.
senses.example: The disease was mainly communicated via rats and other vermin.

senses.difference: (transitive) To impart information or knowledge of; to make known, to tell.
senses.example: It is vital that I communicate this information to you.

senses.difference: (transitive|archaic) To share (in); to have in common, to partake of.
senses.example: We shall now consider those functions of intelligence which man communicates with the higher beasts.

senses.difference: (intransitive) To receive or take part in Holy Communion.
senses.example: She attended church, but did not communicate at mass.

senses.difference: (intransitive) To express or convey ideas, either through verbal or nonverbal means; to have intercourse, to exchange information.
senses.example: Many deaf people communicate with sign language.

senses.difference: bend, crook
(transitive) To cause to swerve from a straight course.
senses.example: to curve a ball in pitching it

senses.difference: (intransitive) To bend or turn gradually from a given direction.
senses.example: the road curves to the right

senses.difference: (transitive) To make something less bright.
(intransitive) To become darker.
expose something previously covered
To find something for the first time.
senses.example: Turning the corner, I discovered a lovely little shop.

senses.difference: (intransitive) To be unsuccessful.
senses.example: Throughout my life, I have always failed.

senses.difference: not achieve a goal
be negligent
{{intransitive|of a machine, etc.}} To cease to operate correctly.
senses.example: After running five minutes, the engine failed.

senses.difference: cause to fail
(transitive) To possess, own, hold.
senses.example: I have a house and a car.

senses.difference: to be related to
to partake of something
auxiliary used in forming the perfect and the past perfect tenses
{{context|auxiliary verb, taking a to-infinitive}} must.
senses.example: I have to go.

senses.difference: (transitive) To give birth to.
senses.example: The couple always wanted to have children.

senses.difference: (transitive) To engage in sexual intercourse with.
senses.example: He's always bragging about how many women he's had.

senses.difference: cause to, by command or request
(transitive with adjective or adjective-phrase complement) To cause to be.
senses.example: She had him arrested for trespassing.

senses.difference: (transitive with bare infinitive) To be affected by an occurrence. (Used in supplying a topic that is not a verb argument.)
senses.example: The hospital had several patients contract pneumonia last week.

senses.difference: (transitive with adjective or adjective-phrase complement) To depict as being.
senses.example: Their stories differed; he said he'd been at work when the incident occurred, but her statement had him at home that entire evening.

senses.difference: Used as interrogative auxiliary verb with a following pronoun to form tag questions. (For further discussion, see "Usage notes" below)
senses.example: We haven't eaten dinner yet, have we?

senses.difference: (intransitive) To propel oneself rapidly upward such that momentum causes the body to become airborne.
senses.example: The boy jumped over a fence.

senses.difference: (intransitive) To cause oneself to leave an elevated location and fall downward.
(intransitive) To employ a parachute to leave an aircraft or elevated location.
react to a sudden stimulus by jerking the body violently
employ a move in certain board games in which one piece moves over another
(transitive) To move to a position in (a queue/line) that is further forward.
(intransitive) To be alive; to have life.
senses.example: He's not expected to live for more than a few months.

senses.difference: (intransitive) To have permanent residence somewhere.
senses.example: I live at 2a Acacia Avenue.

senses.difference: survive, persevere
{{intransitive|often|with "at"}} To try to see, to pay attention to with one’s eyes.
senses.example: Look at my new car!

senses.difference: To appear, to seem.
senses.example: It looks as if it’s going to rain soon.

senses.difference: {{intransitive|often|with "for"}} To search for, to try to find.
To face or present a view.
senses.example: The hotel looks over the valleys of the HinduKush.

senses.difference: To expect or anticipate.
senses.example: I look to each hour for my lover’s arrival.

senses.difference: to construct
to produce
To create, construct or produce.
senses.example: We made a bird feeder for our yard.

senses.difference: To constitute.
senses.example: They make a cute couple.

senses.difference: {{context|construed with of|typically interrogative}} To interpret.
senses.example: I don’t know what to make of it.

senses.difference: {{context|usually stressed}} To bring into success.
senses.example: This company is what made you.

senses.difference: {{context|second object is an adjective}} To cause to be.
senses.example: The citizens made their objections clear.

senses.difference: {{context|second object is a verb}} To cause to do.
senses.example: You’re making her cry.

senses.difference: {{context|second object is a verb|can be stressed for emphasis or clarity}} To force to do.
senses.example: The teacher made the student study.

senses.difference: {{context|of a fact}} To indicate or suggest to be.
senses.example: His past mistakes don’t make him a bad person.

senses.difference: {{context|of a person being sought}} To recognise (without being recognised in return).
(transitive) To cause to become.
senses.example: The shot rendered her immobile.

senses.difference: (transitive) To interpret, give an interpretation or rendition of.
senses.example: The pianist rendered the Beethoven sonata beautifully.

senses.difference: (transitive) To pass down.
senses.example: render a verdict (= deliver a judgment)

senses.difference: (transitive) To make over as a return.
senses.example: They had to render the estate.

senses.difference: (transitive) To give; to give back.
senses.example: render aid

senses.difference: {{transitive|computer graphics}} To transform digital information in the form received from a repository into a display on a computer screen, or for other presentation to the user.
senses.example: rendering images

senses.difference: (transitive) To capture and turn over to another country secretly.
To pronounce.
senses.example: Please say your name slowly and clearly.

senses.difference: To recite.
senses.example: Martha, will you say grace?

senses.difference: to communicate verbally or in writing
To indicate in a written form.
senses.example: The sign says it’s 50 kilometres to Paris.

senses.difference: (informal|imperative) Let's say.
to grab with the hands
(transitive) To grab and move to oneself.
senses.example: I’ll take that plate off the table.

senses.difference: (transitive) To get into one's possession.
(transitive) To accept.
senses.example: Do you take sugar in your coffee?

senses.difference: (transitive|military) To gain a position by force.
senses.example: After a bloody battle, they were able to take the city.

senses.difference: to have sex with by force
(transitive) To carry, particularly to a particular destination.
senses.example: I'll take the plate with me.

senses.difference: (transitive) To choose.
senses.example: I'll take the blue plates.

senses.difference: (transitive) To support or carry without failing or breaking.
senses.example: That truck bed will only take two tons.

senses.difference: (transitive) To endure or cope with.
senses.example: I can take the noise, but I can't take the smell.

senses.difference: (transitive) To ingest medicine, drugs, etc.
senses.example: I take aspirin every day to thin my blood.

senses.difference: (transitive) To last or expend [an amount of time].
senses.example: I estimate the trip will take about ten minutes.
